unnormalised: ## A Little Goes a Long Way: My Diwali Donation Drive
normalised: A Little Goes a Long Way: My Diwali Donation Drive

unnormalised: Diwali has always been more than just lights and sweets for my family. It’s a time for reflection, gratitude, and giving back to the community. This year, I wanted to do something a bit more impactful than just donating old clothes. I decided to organize a small donation drive to support the local orphanage, "Sneha Sadan," in Andheri. I started with a humble target: Rs. 5000 to buy some basic necessities.
normalised: Diwali has always been more than just lights and sweets for my family. It’s a time for reflection, gratitude, and giving back to the community. This year, I wanted to do something a bit more impactful than just donating old clothes. I decided to organize a small donation drive to support the local orphanage, "Sneha Sadan," in Andheri. I started with a humble target: rupee five thousand to buy some basic necessities.

unnormalised: My initial plan was simple: ask friends and family. I put up a WhatsApp status explaining my initiative, promising full transparency about how the funds would be used. Within hours, I was pleasantly surprised. My cousin, Priya, immediately transferred Rs. 1000 via UPI. My childhood friend, Rohan, donated Rs. 500. Even my bua in Delhi chipped in with Rs. 2000.
normalised: My initial plan was simple: ask friends and family. I put up a WhatsApp status explaining my initiative, promising full transparency about how the funds would be used. Within hours, I was pleasantly surprised. My cousin, Priya, immediately transferred rupee one thousand via U-P-I. My childhood friend, Rohan, donated rupee five hundred. Even my bua in Delhi chipped in with rupee two thousand.

unnormalised: The momentum continued on social media. I posted a link to a fundraising page, detailing the specific needs of Sneha Sadan. I mentioned that just Rs. 250 could provide a week's worth of nutritious meals for one child. I also highlighted that Rs. 1000 could buy educational supplies.
normalised: The momentum continued on social media. I posted a link to a fundraising page, detailing the specific needs of Sneha Sadan. I mentioned that just rupee two hundred and fifty could provide a week's worth of nutritious meals for one child. I also highlighted that rupee one thousand could buy educational supplies.

unnormalised: I received a notification: someone had donated Rs. 50! I was a little surprised at first, but then I realized that every single contribution, no matter how small, mattered. It was a student, apparently, saving up from his pocket money. It reminded me that generosity isn't about the amount, but about the intention. Every rupee contributed to the cause counts.
normalised: I received a notification: someone had donated rupee fifty! I was a little surprised at first, but then I realized that every single contribution, no matter how small, mattered. It was a student, apparently, saving up from his pocket money. It reminded me that generosity isn't about the amount, but about the intention. Every rupee contributed to the cause counts.

unnormalised: Soon, the donations started flowing in from unexpected sources. An old colleague from my previous company donated Rs. 2500. A kind stranger, moved by my story, contributed Rs. 1500. The total quickly surpassed my initial goal of Rs. 5000. By the end of the week, we had collected a grand total of Rs. 12750.
normalised: Soon, the donations started flowing in from unexpected sources. An old colleague from my previous company donated rupee two thousand five hundred. A kind stranger, moved by my story, contributed rupee one thousand five hundred. The total quickly surpassed my initial goal of rupee five thousand. By the end of the week, we had collected a grand total of rupee twelve thousand seven hundred and fifty.

unnormalised: With the collected funds, we were able to purchase not just basic necessities, but also some much-needed educational toys and books for the children at Sneha Sadan. Seeing their faces light up when we delivered the items was an incredibly rewarding experience.
normalised: With the collected funds, we were able to purchase not just basic necessities, but also some much-needed educational toys and books for the children at Sneha Sadan. Seeing their faces light up when we delivered the items was an incredibly rewarding experience.

unnormalised: This Diwali, I learned that even the smallest act of kindness can make a huge difference. And that sometimes, the best way to celebrate is by sharing our blessings with those who are less fortunate. I’m already planning my next donation drive, hoping to raise even more than Rs. 12750!
